definition[0]: the feeling you have when you feel guilty and embarrassed because you, or someone who is close to you, have done something wrong
example[0]: He felt a deep sense of shame.
example[2]: To her shame (=it made her feel ashamed), she gained back all the weight she’d lost.
example[3]: He’s brought shame on the whole family.
example[4]: There’s no shame in (=it should not make you feel ashamed) saying ‘I don’t know.’
example[5]: I bow my head in shame when I think of how I treated her.
example[6]: How could you do such a thing? Have you no shame?
example[7]: She never overcame the shame of having abandoned her children.
example[8]: He remembered his angry words with a deep sense of shame.
example[9]: Following the scandal, Garrison resigned in shame.
definition[2]: a feeling of shame and embarrassment because you have been made to look weak or stupid in front of other people
example[10]: What really upset me was the humiliation of having to ask her for money.
example[11]: He suffered the humiliation of defeat in the first round of the competition.
definition[3]: the loss of other people’s respect because you have done something bad, or you have been unsuccessful
example[12]: His comments have brought shame and dishonour on him and his profession.
example[13]: There is no dishonour in failure when you have done everything you possibly can to succeed.
definition[4]: the feeling that other people in society disapprove of you because of something that has happened to you, or because you feel different from most other people in some way – used especially when this seems unfair and unreasonable
example[14]: Even when someone has been found innocent of a crime, the stigma often remains.
example[15]: At first I found the stigma of being unemployed very difficult to cope with.
example[16]: In many countries there is still a strong social stigma attached to homosexuality.
definition[5]: a complete loss of people’s respect because you have done something very bad and shocking
example[17]: His actions brought disgrace on the family.
example[18]: The players were sent home in disgrace after admitting taking drugs.
example[19]: Garton killed himself because he could not bear the disgrace of being charged with corruption.
definition[6]: a feeling of great shame and embarrassment because you have been made to look weak or stupid – a very formal use
example[20]: The team suffered the ignominy of losing five games in a row.
example[21]: She hoped to avoid the ignominy of having to appear in court.
example[22]: It shames me to say it, but I lied.
example[23]: He felt shamed and humiliated by the treatment he had received.
definition[8]: to be so much better than someone else that you make them seem bad or feel embarrassed
example[24]: Their training record shamed other companies.
definition[9]: to make someone feel they have lost all honour and respect
example[25]: She had shamed her family name  (=done something that made her family lose honour).
